# ğŸ–¼ï¸ ggplot2 4.0.0 â€” Beginner-Friendly Overview

Most of your old plots will still work the same, but here are the big wins in version 4.0.0:

- ğŸ¨ **Themes got easier**: more automatic styling (ink = main elements, paper = background, accent = highlights).
- ğŸ—‚ï¸ **Facets (small multiples)**: more layout options, panels can size to their data, and flexible data repetition.
- ğŸ“Š **Geoms (shapes)**: Boxplots, violins, and labels have more styling options; area/ribbon plots can use gradients.
- ğŸ›ï¸ **Scales & axes**: minor ticks for categorical axes, easier axis reversal, and smarter secondary axes.
- ğŸ“ **Labels**: can auto-use variable labels or a dictionary you provide.
- ğŸ› ï¸ **Errors**: clearer error messages when you give bad input.

ğŸ‘‰ Bottom line: plots still work the same, but you get more control and friendlier defaults.

# ğŸš€ Practice Examples

Each example highlights one beginner-friendly feature of ggplot2 4.0.0, with ideas for things you can try.

---

## 1. Style boxplots more easily

Look for: light blue box fill, red median line, dashed whiskers.

```{r boxplot}
ggplot(mpg, aes(class, hwy)) +
  geom_boxplot(
    fill = "lightblue",        # inside the box
    box.colour = "blue",       # outline of the box
    median.colour = "red",     # median line
    whisker.linetype = "dashed"
  )

# ğŸ‘‰ Try changing fill = "pink" or "green" to experiment.
# ğŸ‘‰ Map a variable: geom_boxplot(aes(fill = drv)) to color by drive type.
# ğŸ‘‰ Adjust median.linetype = "dotted" or median.linewidth = 2.
```

---

## 2. Try facet layouts

Look for: small multiples starting bottom-right, wrapping across rows.

```{r facets}
ggplot(mpg, aes(displ, hwy)) +
  geom_point() +
  facet_wrap(~class, dir = "br")  # bottom-right start

# ğŸ‘‰ Try dir = "tl", "rb", or "tr" to see different starting corners.
# ğŸ‘‰ Try facet_grid(drv ~ cyl) for a grid layout instead of wrap.
# ğŸ‘‰ Add scales = "free" to let each panel set its own axis limits.
```

---

## 3. Add minor ticks to categorical axes

Look for: tiny extra tick marks on the x-axis (between categories).

```{r minor-ticks}
ggplot(mpg, aes(class, hwy)) +
  geom_point() +
  scale_x_discrete(minor_breaks = 1:7)

# ğŸ‘‰ Try scale_y_continuous(minor_breaks = seq(10, 50, by = 2)).
# ğŸ‘‰ Remove them: scale_x_discrete(minor_breaks = NULL).
```

---

## 4. Gradient fills in area plots

Look for: area shaded with a gradient that changes with unemployment levels.

```{r gradient-fill}
ggplot(economics, aes(date, unemploy, fill = unemploy)) +
  geom_area()

# ğŸ‘‰ Try changing fill = pop to see population instead of unemployment.
# ğŸ‘‰ Try geom_ribbon(aes(ymin = unemploy - 500, ymax = unemploy + 500, fill = unemploy)).
```

---

## 5. Use a label dictionary

Look for: axis labels automatically replaced with nicer text.

```{r labels-dictionary}
labels <- c(displ = "Engine Size (L)", hwy = "Highway MPG")

ggplot(mpg, aes(displ, hwy)) +
  geom_point() +
  labs(dictionary = labels)

# ğŸ‘‰ Add more entries to the dictionary to rename multiple variables at once.
# ğŸ‘‰ Try labs(title = "Car Efficiency", subtitle = "Displacement vs Highway MPG").
```
